page_analysis.text_content:
Step 2: Determine which perimeter segments abut the house walls. These are closed segments, or sides.

In Fig 5 sides A, B, & C abut the house walls.
These are considered to be closed segments.

Step 3: Determine the status (open/closed) of the remaining segments based on the design. If at least 50% of the facade area is open, then the segment or side is considered open.

For purposes of assessing the openess of the facade:

• The height of the segment facades is measured from the top of the porch floor to the the point where the segment facade intersects with the top of the roof material.

• The widths of the segment facades are measured from the same plane. Allowances may be made for structural supports that are not excessive.

visual_elements.description: Floor plan diagram labeled as Fig 5 showing a house layout with segments A, B, and C marked as closed segments abutting house walls. The diagram shows dimensions and includes an angled section marked with measurements.

Cross-sectional elevation diagrams showing four different facade segments (D, E, F, G) with measurements. Shows height measurement of 8' from porch floor to roof intersection, and widths of 7', 14', 24', and 4' respectively. Segments are labeled as Open, Closed, Open, Open from left to right.

additional_notes: Diagram includes labels for segments A, B, C as closed segments
Cross-sectional diagrams show structural details including porch floor and roof intersection

sides A, B, & C abut the house walls. These are considered to be closed segments

logical_relationships.expression: If at least 50% of the facade area is open, then the segment or side is considered open

execution_sequence.action: Determine which perimeter segments abut the house walls
Determine the status (open/closed) of the remaining segments
Measure facade height and width according to specified criteria
